---
slug: /231
title: "This Week In React #231: React Labs, Compiler, React Router, Next.js, TanStack Query, c15t, RTK, Base UI | Legend List, FlashList, Versioning, Metro, ExecuTorch, Brownfield, Expo Router | TC39, Surveys, Rspack, tsdown"
authors: [matthieugicquel, cyrilbo]
date: 04-23-2025
---
Hi everyone!
Cyril and Matthieu from [Theodo Apps](https://apps.theodo.com/en?utm_source=thisweekinreact) here ğŸ‘‹, standing in for Seb to bring you the latest news from the React and React Native worlds.
This week, we have two exciting blog posts for the React team, and a special guest from the React core team has a message for you all!
We've also been reading quite a few interesting blog posts from the "official" blogs and the community.
<!-- truncate -->
import Support from "@site/newsletter/_support.mdx";
<Support />
## ğŸ’¸ Sponsor {#sponsor1}
[![Convex: The Database Designed for AI Coding](/emails/issues/227/convex.jpg)](https://convex.link/thisweekai)
**[Convex: The Database Designed for AI Coding](https://convex.link/thisweekai)**

In the age of code generation, you need a backend that you can confidently generate with AI platforms. Convex is by far and away [best in class](https://stack.convex.dev/introducing-fullstack-bench) in this respect.
This is because Convex is just TypeScript, allowing you to writeÂ [queries as code](https://docs.convex.dev/functions/query-functions/)Â that are automatically transactional, cached, and realtime.
And thatâ€™s just the beginning. With Convex, you can:

* Easily schedule functions and write cron jobs
* Set up file storage
* Write efficient server functions
* And so much moreâ€¦
[Try a Quickstart today](https://docs.convex.dev/quickstarts)
## ğŸ“£ From the React team {#react-core-team}
[![React Labs: View Transitions, Activity, and more](/emails/issues/231/labs.jpg)](https://react.dev/blog/2025/04/23/react-labs-view-transitions-activity-and-more)
**[React Labs: View Transitions, Activity, and more](https://react.dev/blog/2025/04/23/react-labs-view-transitions-activity-and-more)**
The rumors youâ€™ve heard that the React Team only cares about the server have been greatly exaggerated.

In our [React Labs post](https://react.dev/blog/2025/04/23/react-labs-view-transitions-activity-and-more) today, we shared that [View Transitions](https://react.dev/reference/react/ViewTransition) and [Activity](https://react.dev/reference/react/Activity) are now ready to try out in our experimental channel, along with docs for each. These new features allow React running on the client to animate UI transitions, and hide and show parts of the UI as the user navigates client-side. They work with server features, but are aimed at solving problems on the client.

We also [shared updates](https://react.dev/blog/2025/04/23/react-labs-view-transitions-activity-and-more#features-in-development) on problem areas weâ€™re focusing on that impact client-rendered apps including better profiling tools, automatically compiling effect dependencies, a potential IDE extension, fragment refs, and yes even a concurrent store. These are problem areas weâ€™ve wanted to address for a while, which recent features like the React Compiler and the `use` API allow us to finally tackle.

These features are still early and might change significantly before theyâ€™re ready to try. You can follow along while we build these features, and this newsletter is a great way to stay up to date. But donâ€™t stress about learning everything - you can let us cook first.
When weâ€™re more confident a feature will ship, weâ€™ll announce it on the blog and publish docs, like weâ€™re doing today for View Transitions and Activity.
Give the new experimental features a try, and check out the areas weâ€™re working on in the [blog post](https://react.dev/blog/2025/04/23/react-labs-view-transitions-activity-and-more).
-[Ricky Hanlon](https://bsky.app/profile/ricky.fm)
## âš›ï¸ React {#react}
[![React Compiler RC](/emails/issues/231/compiler.jpg)](https://react.dev/blog/2025/04/21/react-compiler-rc)
**[React Compiler RC](https://react.dev/blog/2025/04/21/react-compiler-rc)**
The React Labs post is not the only exciting update this week! The React Compiler is also in Release Candidate, in preparation of the compilerâ€™s stable release.
The Babel-free builds is a welcome improvement so that we can keep using the compiler with our modern Rust tooling!

* ğŸ’¸ [How to build a multi-tenant app using Clerk + Supabase](https://go.clerk.com/j5M7vZt)
* ğŸ—“ [Future Frontend](https://futurefrontend.com/?utm_source=thisweekinreact) - ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡® Espoo - 26-28 May. Dive into the future of frontend development with Aurora Scharff, Rachel Nabors, and others! Use code "TWIR" for a 10% discount.
* ğŸ“œ [Impossible Components](https://overreacted.io/impossible-components/): Dan Abramov continues his series of blog posts about RSC, this time detailing, among other things, how it squares with Reactâ€™s top-down data flow.
* ğŸ“œ [Faster Lazy Loading in React Router v7.5+](https://remix.run/blog/faster-lazy-loading): This was released a few weeks ago. Mark Dalgleish explains in this post why the new approach (lazy loading by route properties instead of the whole route) was necessary, especially when using middlewares.
* ğŸ“œ [Performance tips with Next.js](https://vercel.com/blog/guide-to-fast-websites-with-next-js-tips-for-maximizing-server-speeds#how-to-speed-up-the-page-render-minimize-client-burden): A nice recap of all the available optimizations: pre-render, use caching, watch bundle size, lazy-load what can be, optimize fonts and images, use virtualizationâ€¦
* ğŸ“œ [Simplify TanStack React Query State Handling with Pattern Matching](https://gabrielpichot.fr/blog/simplify-tanstack-react-query-state-handling-with-pattern-matching/)
* ğŸ“œ [Using Client Caches In Loaders](https://www.brenelz.com/posts/using-client-caches-in-loaders/)
* ğŸ“œ [Life of a Request: Application-aware routing - Vercel](https://vercel.com/blog/life-of-a-request-application-aware-routing)
* ğŸ“œ [Tailwind vs Linaria: Performance Investigation](https://www.developerway.com/posts/tailwind-vs-linaria-performance)
* ğŸ“¦ [c15t](https://github.com/c15t/c15t): A new consent management framework coming with drop-in React components.
* ğŸ“¦ [Redux Toolkit 2.7](https://github.com/reduxjs/redux-toolkit/releases/tag/v2.7.0): Standard Schema for RTK query, improved infinite queries.
* ğŸ“¦ [Headless Tree 1.0](https://headless-tree.lukasbach.com/): A successor to React Complex tree, the author has a [blog post explaining the change](https://medium.com/@lukasbach/headless-tree-and-the-future-of-react-complex-tree-fc920700e82a).
* ğŸ“¦ [Module Federation Core 0.13](https://github.com/module-federation/core/releases/tag/v0.13.0): Better React 19 support and bug fixes.
* ğŸ“¦ [Base UI 1.0 alpha-8](https://github.com/mui/base-ui/releases/tag/v1.0.0-alpha.8): The new Radix UI alternative keeps progressing with new Toast and Meter components among many other things.
* ğŸ™ï¸ [Syntax.fm - React Server Components: Where are we at?](https://syntax.fm/show/895/react-server-components-where-are-we-at)

segments.source_content: <SubscribeFormEmbed placement="middle" />
## ğŸ’¸ Sponsor {#sponsor2}
[![Self-service analytics and dashboards in your product](/emails/issues/231/semaphor.jpg)](https://semaphor.cloud)
**[Self-service analytics and dashboards in your product](https://semaphor.cloud)**

**Your engineers didnâ€™t sign up to build dashboards.**
Let them focus on features.
With Semaphor, your data team can ship insights independently. No code changes, no front-end redeploys. Decouple analytics from your product code and move faster.
## ğŸ“± React-Native {#react-native}
[![Legend List 1.0](/emails/issues/231/legend-list.png)](https://bsky.app/profile/jayz.us/post/3lni5ofbuvs2s)
**[Legend List 1.0](https://bsky.app/profile/jayz.us/post/3lni5ofbuvs2s)**

Making long lists performant is a hard problem, and React Nativeâ€™s old architecture wasnâ€™t making it any easier with itâ€™s asynchronous layout computation. We remember Margelo abandoning their `WishList` project.
Legend List is now in version 1.0, and promises to be even faster than `FlashList`, all the while handling the "hard cases": bidirectional infinite lists, varying item sizesâ€¦ And it's compatible with the old arch (though less performant and with possible glitches).

As Seb mentioned last week, thereâ€™s also a [v2 of `FlashList`](https://github.com/Shopify/flash-list/tree/new-rlv-prototype) in the works, which should be easier to use (no need to specify estimatedItemSize for instance).
Thankfully, all those copy the API of `FlatList` so itâ€™s easy to switch back and forth ğŸ™‚.

* ğŸ’¸ [PostHog - How to set up React Native session replay](https://go.posthog.com/twir-apr23)
* ğŸ¦ [Prototype of Module Federation working with Metro Bundler](https://x.com/_jbroma/status/1912903068464594993)
* ğŸ¦ [An experiment of CSS support in React Native, including grid layout](https://x.com/mani3xis/status/1912947427864441144)
* ğŸ“– [React Native Versioning Policy](https://reactnative.dev/contributing/versioning-policy): This new page details the versioning scheme based on the `0.x.y` pattern. Even more importantly, this also explains the release process and what is considered a breaking change. This is part of an ongoing effort to clarify the public API surface and even reduce it (see the [Removing deep imports RFC](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals/pull/894)). React Native is getting more stable, and maybe weâ€™ll get a v1.0 one day?
* ğŸ“œ [Best Practices for reducing lag in Expo apps](https://expo.dev/blog/best-practices-for-reducing-lag-in-expo-apps): Highlight React renders directly from the devtools, React Compiler, React 19, and multi-threading.
* ğŸ“œ [Offline Text Recognition on Mobile: How We Brought EasyOCR to React Native ExecuTorch](https://blog.swmansion.com/bringing-easyocr-to-react-native-executorch-2401c09c2d0c)
* ğŸ“œ [How to build universal app voice agents with Expo & ElevenLabs](https://expo.dev/blog/how-to-build-universal-app-voice-agents-with-expo-and-elevenlabs)
* ğŸ“œ [Out with the old, in with the New Architecture (by default)](https://expo.dev/blog/out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new-architecture)
* ğŸ“¦ [React Native Brownfield 1.0](https://github.com/callstack/react-native-brownfield/releases/tag/v1.0.0): Adds support for SwiftUI, Jetpack Compose, and packaging as a framework.
* ğŸ“¦ [typegpu-confetti](https://github.com/software-mansion-labs/typegpu-confetti): Confetti animations for React Native, computed and rendered exclusively on the GPU with `react-native-webgpu` and TypeGPU.
* ğŸ¥ [Expo Router Tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLsXDmrmFV_AT17JDf-otXSNE_eH7s0uDD): The first 5 videos are available. It covers layout files, Stack & Tab navigators, modals, and Auth Flow.
* ğŸ™ï¸ [RNR 328 - Flashlight with Alexandre Moureaux](https://infinite.red/react-native-radio/rnr-328-flashlight-with-alexandre-moureaux)
* ğŸ™ï¸ [Rocket Ship 65 - Expo SDK 53 Preview, RevenueCat Paywalls, AI Images & Gemini](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=evGUO_CN1Fc)
